thread.section_title: Foreign and national political news and analysis - San Francisco Chronicle
thread.title: Again? Health care debate expands for 2016
thread.title_full: Again? Health care debate expands for 2016 - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Ricardo Alonso-zaldivar, Associated Press
title: Again? Health care debate expands for 2016
text: Photo: Paul Beaty, AP In this Sept. 28, 2015, photo, Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt. speaks at the University of Chicago in Chicago. After seven years of the political drama known as "Obamacare," you might think voters would be tired of big ideas for revamping health care. If so, the presidential candidates seem to have missed the memo. On the left, part of the appeal of Sanders is his years-long advocacy of "single payer," a tax-supported, Medicare-like plan for all. The idea is in the political DNA of liberals, and Sanders as president would lead a movement to make it happen, his campaign says. In this Sept. 28, 2015, photo, Democratic presidential candidate... WASHINGTON (AP) — America's health care debate has been called an unhealthy political obsession. But if the 2016 presidential hopefuls have any say, it's about to get bigger. In this Sept. 28, 2015, photo, Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt. speaks at the University of Chicago in Chicago. After seven years of the political drama known as "Obamacare," you might think voters would be tired of big ideas for revamping health care. If so, the presidential candidates seem to have missed the memo. On the left, part of the appeal of Sanders is his years-long advocacy of "single payer," a tax-supported, Medicare-like plan for all.
